text: From can. Orange-amber clear with thin white lacing head. Mild sweet nose with a bit of corn and oxidation. Light whiff of noble hop character. Fairly clean pils profile, light sweet with a little corn and oxidation. Medium bitter finish with clean after.

Pours a straw yellow with a thin white head. Aroma is grass, pine, herbal notes, and bread. Flavor is grass, pine, herbal and floral notes with the malts more muted. Has a low bitterness. Pretty good.
From a 16 oz can. Pours a hazy straw color with a large foamy head. Notes of catty hops, sweet bread, and lemon zest. Hops seem a bit faded.

Pour out of 16 oz can, hazy straw yellow pour with white head, aroma brought notes of bread, dough, slight lemon peel into grass, spice, touch of yeasty notes as well with a hint of grain, herbal notes. Taste was a mix of grass, spice, some lemon into a bit of earth, spice, touch of bread, finishing bitter. Not bad.

16 oz can: Aroma has got a nice Saaz hop note maybe some Hellertau with little or no malt characteristics. Appearance is a golden pour with a thick white head that diminishes slowly. Taste is quite nice for a Czech Pilsner with a nice pungent grassy hop note and smooth and clean on the aftertaste. Overall, an enjoyable drinker. Cheers!

Can at home. Purchased at Sicilianos in GR. Pours a light golden yellow with a thin white head. Aroma is slight corn and light floral. Flavor follows with nice bitterness. Nice beer. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

16 oz. can. Pours a golden orange with a thick white head. Nice lacing. Aroma of spicy hops, pils malt, bread notes. Flavor is hop forward, bitter. With bready sweetness. Medium bodied, average carbonation. Finishes bitter and hoppy. Nice little lager.

Ive had this straight from the can and in various glasses. Pale straw color. Big, big head so it must be opened and poured carefully; susceptible to gushing if the can is even slightly shaken. Mild, clean taste of bready, sweet malt; hints of grass and spice. I really like this, glad it comes in pint cans.

Can. Hazy golden body with a big frothy, white head, slowly diminishing  probably because this was a gusher. Aroma of butterscotch and more butterscotch with just a hint of sulfur, toasted grain. The flavor is moderately sweet and moderately bitter. It finishes lightly to moderately sweet and lightly bitter. Medium body, buttery/sticky texture, lively carbonation. Dirty, diacetyl-laden, infected, overly bitter. Looks good, though.

On tap: The aroma consists of light-moderate grass, light honey, and bread. Its a transparent gold with a two finger head that eventually fades to a thin film. There is a thin sheet of lacing left on the sides of the glass. The flavor starts with light honey and lightly sweet cereal/grain notes. The finish has light-moderate grass/straw. Its light bodied with soft carbonation and mouthfeel. Overall, a really nice Pilsner. Ive passed on this is cans several times. Hopefully it translates in cans as well as it does on tap.
Poured a cloudy yellowish color from the can with aromas of grass, light spice, some floral notes aromas cereal. Flavors matched the aromas, meh overall.
Can from Sicilianos. Pours yellow with a thick white head. Leaves a lot of lacing. Nice hop aroma. Solid floral notes with enough bitterness to keep things interesting. Nice example of style.

Draft sample. Poured a clear amber color with an average frothy white head that was lasting and produced excellent lacing. Moderate hop and yeast aroma. Medium body with a smooth texture and soft carbonation. Medium sweet flavor with with a medium sweet finish of moderate duration. Nice beer.

Drank straight from the can in my hotel room. Strong grassy nose, follows in taste, so much grass it almost comes off as skunk... But its not. Mild malt sweetness, ample bitterness that lingers long after the sip. Light body, pretty good pils.

can. pours hazy and almost cloudy pale but bright yellow with a creamy white head offering good retention and strong lacing. fresh grains and cereals, insanely fragrant - flowers, spices, citrus, chewy pils, fruity - white grapes - pinot-gris-like, minerals - touch of sulfur, bright citrus, clean yeast esters - slight dustiness, hint of sweetness. healthy carbonation - prickles a bit, light body - oily, relatively dry, smooth yet crisp spicy-citrusy finish. very pleasant surprise!

Can from Angelis in the U.P. Pours hazy golden with moderate to thick pillowy white head. Nose is hoppy with floral, resiny and even slightly pine-like. More rich bready malt notes as the head dissolves after some time - this is actually when the balance achieves a definite bo-pils quality. Flavor is somewhat hop-dominated with a resiny bite of bitter grapefruit peel. Finishes with a long lasting bitter hoppiness. For the style, I prefer a softer balance of hops and malt that really showcases the purity of the water, malts and yeast but this is a tasty take on the classic style - leans towards the hoppy in a big way, but has a nice bready malt profile beneath.

On tap, poured into a sampler glass. The aroma has a bit of a banana and vanilla note with some cereal, and black pepper. It pours a clear, pale gold color with a white, small bubble head. It reduces to a medium ring with a dusty surface and leaves an abundant sheet lace. The taste is a medium light bitter with a medium sweetness to it. The oily textured beer has a medium light body and a zippy carbonation. Theres tones of cereal, grain, a light citrus, a dry, clean pine and a mineral note in the finish. the pine and mineral stick around with a bit of pepper in the aftertaste.
Very easy drinking sessionable beer. Not much bitterness at 35 ibu felt. On tap at the brewery.

16oz can, thanks to umich03jm, Im pretty sure. Pours a beautiful orange amber color. Perfect thin finger of off-white head, that leaves great, thicker lace. Medium body. Super smooth, kind of crisp, lighter carbonation. Good creamy texture to the full mouthfeel. Supremely swiggable. Goddamn, this is a good pils. Great bready, lightly peppery malt. Some nice light herbal hop to it. Moderate sweet taste, nice moderate bitter. Freakin fantastic pilsener. A wonderful one to enjoy with my sandwich. I had to be careful to not chug this whole thing in one gulp, so I could pick it apart for my reviews. I will be picking this up again, if I ever see it on a shelf. If I had another 16oz can Id have cracked it open right now and kept on raving. Will definitely have to revisit at length in the future..

Pint can at hopcat pours a bright clear golden/yellow with a large white head. Nice yeast and graham cracker malt aroma with bright hops. Taste of sweet caramel biscuit malt, nice yeast presence, bittering grassy hops on the outside of the palate. Light, tasty, and refreshing.

UPDATED: SEP 24, 2014 
More body than any other Pilsner that I have tried. Slightly cloudy golden color. Lots of hops in both aroma and taste, but bitterness balanced with malt mouth feel.

Can. Pours a very cloudy pale orange color with a small frothy head that sits there nicely. Leaves some lacing when it fades. Aroma has piles of noble hops. Big spicy, grassy, and herbal hops plus some nice crackers and sugar cookie malt. Taste is malt up front and a big spicy hop bit in the finish. Nice sugar cookie sweetness. Moderate bitterness. Crisp finish, slightly dry. Medium to thick body. Very nice czech pilsner. The big body and extra spicy hops make this more of a sipper which is very unique. Good summer sipping beer by the pool.
can. golden with one finger head. mild body with some cracker and a bit of sweetness. pretty substantial hops in the finish.

16oz can - pours a medium dark gold with fluffy off white head . Nice lacing . Spicy hop aromas . Taste is herbal and spicy with a nice malt sweetness . Clean finish . A well done pilsner . 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

16 ounce can

A new Michigan brewery is never something to pass up. This was a Bohemian pilsener with a Midwestern demeanor. While not my favorite beer the fact that it is an affordable can gives it a place in the list of breweries to keep an eye on.

Aroma / Appearance - A rich white head slowly collapses to a thin foam. A semitransparent rose gold base radiates gentleness. Wheaty hops, cereal grains, and a warm loaf of fresh white bread linger in the air like a bakery in production mode.

Flavor / Palate - Creamy sherry, lemons, and bitter oranges glaze the tongue with a burst of hops. Granola and tea transition to a malty finish. A nice finish tastes like dusty book bindings. Id love to try a few more Bohemian pilseners to get a handle on the style.
Can. Clear gold with nice white head. Always like . Hay and malt. Nice light with good bitter bite for pils-- rated with beerbasher
Can. Clear gold with a light head. Sweet hay and light pils. Clean with a nice, slightly bitter bite.

16 ounce can into lager glass, no canning date. Pours fairly crystal clear bright golden amber color with a 1 finger dense white head with great retention that reduces to a nice cap that lasts. Spotty soapy lacing clings down the glass, with a good amount of streaming carbonation retaining the head. Aromas of lemon zest, orange zest, pear, cracker, bread, pepper, light pine, floral, grass, herbal, and yeast earthiness. Very nice aromas with good balance of hop, malt, yeast ester notes; with good strength. Taste of lemon zest, orange zest, pear, cracker, bread, pepper, pine, herbal, floral, grass, and yeast earthiness. Good amount of spicy pepper/pine bitterness on the finish; with lingering notes of lemon zest, orange zest, pear, cracker, bread, pepper, pine, floral, grass, and yeast earthiness on the finish for a good bit. Very nice balance of malt, hop, and yeast ester flavors; with a very crisp malt/bitterness balance and minimal cloying bitterness after the finish. Medium carbonation and body; with a very smooth, crisp, and moderately sticky mouthfeel that is nice. Alcohol is very well hidden with minimal warming present after the finish. Overall this is a damn nice Czech pilsner style! All around good balance of malt, hop, and yeast ester flavors; and extremely crisp and smooth to drink. A very enjoyable offering.

Can. Thanks Sean! Lager and wet pils malt aroma. Starts out bitter, spicy and generally clean, building balance from a nice malt base. The hop bitterness is lean and green, with plant-y vibe, a somewhat uncertain character. Raw. Its mostly fresh, pretty lively, and nicely bitter. Id be very happy to have this readily available. Better than many American renditions.

On tap. Pours a lighter gold, clear, with a white head. Spicy hop and pale malt aroma. Flavor features the spicy hops with more floral hops as well, pale malts, a bit sweeter than the average pilsener. Its a rather tasty one, though.

This was a decent beer but was not unique. It fit the style notes well. Faint grain and lager aroma. Clear golden color with some effervescence. White head. Light palate that was crisp and clean. Slight hops bitterness on the finish. Good carbonation. Standard malt flavors with a good mix of balancing hops. A little grassy but good with food.

Can from Champanes, 
this beer had a very clear straw yellow pour with a bit of gold and gave more than a one finger white head that receded to a thin layer and sticky ring, there were spots and small fingers of lacing on the sides of the glass, 

I thought I noticed a little skunk upon opening the can, the aromas were light malt, cracker, hops were grass and faint floral with very little to no sweetness, and a little skunk in the background, 

flavors were light malt and bread with lots of hop bitterness, no sweetness, 

the mouth feel was light and crisp with average carbonation, 

a nice pilsener, light and crisp in flavor and on the palate.

UPDATED: DEC 9, 2013 Tap: very slightly hazed golden body with a foamy white head that slowly settles to a chunky collar. Aroma has some earthy, slightly spicy, mildly citric hops, light bready underbody with some fresh lemon zest, yeasty finish. Taste has notes of clean lemon & citrus zest, leafy & earthy hops, mild toasty bread, clean yeast finish. Pretty nice pilsner, very high drinkability. Overall, tasty stuff.
On tap at Petes Place. One of the best hoppy pilsners Ive ever had. Really good stuff.
On tap. Bright, clear yellow. Lingering head. Good mouthfeel. Odd sort of spice character, but then Im unfamiliar with Czech style.
Tap. Pours bubbly orange with gorgeous white head. Aroma is nice sticky weed. Taste is banging hops grass and nice crsip fresh finishe
